poem:
### Cinema's Dilemma

In the flicker of reels, nations spar,  
a popcorn drama on the global stage.  
Presidents tweet their critiques—  
a celluloid curtain rises, revealing  
foreign whispers beneath the screen.  
Yet in the dark, rows of seats unite,  
eyes wide, a shared gaze—  
cinema survives, defying the decree.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Ban this foreign filth! Can cinema really threaten national security? As always with pronouncements by President Trump, once you had peeled away the xenophobia, removed the stew of resentment, ignored the sheer idiocy and asterisked the possible illegality, there was a small kernel of truth to his posting on Truth Social last Sunday. “The Movie Industry in America is DYING a very fast death,” he wrote, pointing to the nefarious tax breaks other countries gave". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
